ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CIVIL SERVICE MORALE


    1. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for Finance what is the general morale of workers in the civil service and whether there are plans to further improve management-worker relationship.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the general morale of workers in the Civil Service is excellent. I do not know of any need for special plans to further improve management-workers relations, but I always welcome any suggestions which may be made by Members of Parliament or anyone else. I hope the Member for Mountbatten will write to me if he has any particular point to make. I promise to give it my utmost consideration.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware of a general complaint that there is a lack of consultation between the management and workers within the Civil Service and that instructions are usually shoved down the throats of those at the lower levels without due consideration for their workload?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am not aware of this particular problem. But if there were such a problem, I would expect that a Civil Service association would bring this up or through their unions, that is, the teachers' unions or whatever unions they have.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, in case the Minister for Finance is also not aware, can I raise another point to alert him that there is also a general complaint that suggestions from the workers do not sometimes go up so as to be given due consideration.

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought we welcome suggestions to such an extent that we are prepared to pay for those which are constructive.

KALLANG ESTATE MARKET
(Expansion)


    2. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry has done any recent study on the adequacy of the Kallang Estate Market and whether the Market should be expanded to serve the increasing population in Mountbatten Constituency.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for the Environment)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 1,898 vacant market-produce stalls as at 31st January, 1981. The tight labour situation has given rise to two trends. First, less people are willing to become market-produce hawkers. Secondly, more working families are eating out or are patronizing supermarkets for their daily necessities. We foresee that this trend will continue.

    The Government will convert some vacant market-produce stalls for more productive use and may build smaller markets in future housing estates.

    The Kallang Estate Market has 155 market-produce stalls and 16 cooked-food stalls. Five market-produce stalls there are still vacant. There are also two other markets near the Mountbatten Constituency, namely, Sims Avenue market with 285 stalls, and Jalan Batu market with 166 stalls. These three markets can adequately serve the population in the Mountbatten Constituency.

    Because of the existing high rate of vacant market-produce stalls, my Ministry will not expand the Kallang Estate Market.

CRIME
(Murder cases)


    3. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many murder cases there were since 1st January, 1980, up to the latest convenient date, and how many of those cases are still not solved.

Column: 631



     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there were 62 murder cases in 1980 and 11 in the first two months of 1981.

    Of the 62 murders in 1980, 22 have not been solved. The clearance rate is therefore 65%. Of the 11 murders this year, only two have not been solved. The clearance rate is 82%. These clearance rates compare favourably with those of the preceding three years, which are: 
      Year                    Percentage
      1977                       72%
      1978                       66%
      1979                       57%


     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, are those unsolved cases to be treated as "closed" cases?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, unsolved criminal cases are never treated as "closed" cases.

SINGAPORE POLICE FORCE
(Resignations)


    4. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the recent resignations of officers from the Singapore Police Force have affected the Force and weakened law enforcement; and if his Ministry has taken measures to fill those vacancies and to improve the conditions of service so as to encourage officers to stay on.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, in January this year, seven junior officers resigned from the Police Force. Last month, two senior officers and 26 junior officers resigned.

    Since the introduction of the 13th month pay, February and July each year are the months in which most resignations take place. Those who are thinking of resigning from the Force early in the year will make up their minds by June and resign in July. They know that if they were to wait further, then it would be better to wait till they collect their 13th month pay in December, serve notice of resignation in January and leave in February. Those who have decided to resign in the

Column: 632

second half of the year, therefore, wait till February to leave.

    In 1980, 16 junior officers resigned in February and another 16 resigned in July. However, for the whole year there were only 113 resignations. On average, between nine and 10 junior officers resigned per month. The 113 resignations for the whole year represented only 1.8% of the actual strength of junior officers at the end of that year. Therefore, although the number of resignations in February this year was high, there is no cause for alarm.

    Since the bulk of the resignations is junior officers, they would not adversely affect the Force nor weaken law enforcement. Furthermore, 29 of the 33 junior officers were Constables, and there were only one Sergeant and one Corporal who resigned. Forty-two of them had less than four years' service.

    Resignations represent one side of the coin. The other is recruitment. The staffing position of the Force as reflected in the number of vacancies is the net result of resignations and recruitment. In fact, the position of vacancies in the Police Force has improved over the last four years. In 1977, vacancies accounted for 12.6% of the authorized strength of the Force. Through regular recruitment exercises, the percentage improved to 6.8% in 1978, 7.1% in 1979 and 6.4% in 1980. From 1977 to 1980, 14,976 persons applied to join the Police Force. Of this total, 8,643 were found eligible and subsequently 1,165 were recruited after they had passed the interviews, medical examinations and screening.

    For this year, the Police will hold two recruitment exercises.

    The large numbers of applications received during recruitment exercises indicate that the conditions of service in the Police Force are not unattractive. However, efforts have been made to improve the career prospects of Police Officers. The more significant measures are as follows:

    (1) the introduction of field promotions for outstanding junior officers, soon after they have shown bravery and competence in the

Column: 633

field, and more recently merit promotions for other outstanding junior officers in between the regular bi-annual promotion exercises;

    (2) increased opportunities for junior officers to perform duties of a higher rank so that they can be tested and considered for promotion if they perform well; and

    (3) the introduction of new promotion ranks of Senior Assistant Superintendent of Police and the Deputy Assistant Commissioner of Police.

HDB ONE-ROOM FLATS
(Enlargement of and priority to tenants for transfer to larger units)


    5. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for National Development (a) if the Housing and Development Board will consider giving priority for the purchase of larger units or applications for transfer to larger units to tenants who have lived in HDB one-room flats for eight years or more: and (b) in view of the popularity of the two-room flats, whether the HDB plans to renovate and enlarge the one-room flats to larger units.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are more than 70,000 applicants on the waiting list for HDB flats. A large number have not yet had the chance to live in an HDB flat. It would be unfair to these applicants if priority to purchase is given to existing HDB tenants who are already enjoying the benefits of subsidized housing. Owing to the shortage of flats, it is also not possible to give priority to existing tenants of one-room flats for transfer to larger rental flats.

    I want to add that in my Meet-the-People sessions, a large number of my constituents have asked me to help them get an HDB flat earlier. I want to reiterate here that the HDB's allocation policy is based on registration priority, i.e. first come, first served. No queue jumping on whatever grounds will be allowed even if such requests are made through Members of Parliament, Parliamentary Secretaries, Ministers of State and Ministers. If seeing an MP meant getting an HDB flat earlier, all the 70,000 applicants on

Column: 634

the waiting list will do so, and it is not possible for HDB to grant priority allocation of flats to all of them.

    As the one-room improved flats are still popular, there is no proposal to convert them to larger flats. However, the emergency one-room flats built in the early Sixties are unpopular and many of them are vacant. These flats are now being progressively demolished for redevelopment.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, how does the Minister expect a one-room flat to accommodate a family of 10 persons?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, 10 persons in a family do not arrive suddenly. Previously, the waiting time for HDB flats, both for transfers and for public applications, was 2 1/2 years and now it is about three years. Before the 10 persons arrive, the family should have applied for a transfer earlier. If the family is going to wait for all the 10 persons to arrive before applying for a transfer, then I presume they are able to accommodate themselves somehow.

KIM SENG CONSTITUENCY
(Building of shops and flatted factories)


    6. Dr Yeo Ning Hong asked the Minister for National Development whether, in his redevelopment programme for Kim Seng Constituency, he will consider building shops and flatted factories to provide employment opportunities.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, five blocks of flats, namely, Blocks 63 to 67 at Ganges Avenue have been earmarked for demolition. Demolition will be completed by the end of 1982. A 4-storey block of industrial shops will be built on the site.

HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT
COMPANY
(Income ceiling)


    7. Dr Yeo Ning Hong asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he can give an estimate of the number of Singaporeans who are not eligible

Column: 635

for the Housing and Urban Development Company residential accommodation because of the ceiling on income; and (b) whether the HUDC will be able to cope with the increase in applications if there is no income ceiling.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am unable to give an accurate estimate of the number of Singaporeans who are not eligible for HUDC housing as they have exceeded the income ceiling, because there is a lack of comprehensive family income data in Singapore.

    The Government is not agreeable to the removal of the income ceiling of what is essentially Government-built housing for the middle-income group. However, the income ceiling is periodically adjusted upwards in the light of rising incomes. The ceiling was last revised in April 1980 from $4,000 to $6,000.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister for National Development whether the number of people that he has given to us previously, i.e. people whose income exceeds $2,500, might not be eligible for an HUDC flat if they were to wait for another year or two and then get married to somebody with roughly the same level of income as themselves?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said earlier, the income ceiling will be adjusted upwards periodically. I believe those people whose incomes just exceed $6,000 and at present are ineligible, will become eligible once the income ceiling is revised upwards.

Column: 635

IMPORT OF LIVE PIGS FROM THAILAND


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether it is proposed to import live pigs from Thailand, and, if so, what is the rationale behind the move as local supply is reportedly more than adequate to meet demand and the price of pork has remained reasonable.

Column: 636



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, although we are presently self-sufficient in pork, we cannot maintain this status in the long term. Land presently under farming will increasingly have to make way for other development. Even in the Punggol pig-farming area, land may have to be reallocated for other development in 15 to 20 years' time. Meanwhile, the consumption of pork will increase with increasing affluence and population growth. We are, therefore, looking for alternative sources of pork from abroad.

    We hope that Southern Thailand will eventually become a major source of supply. However, in the next few years, it is unlikely that there will be a large supply of pork coming from Southern Thailand. The Sing Thai Farm, for example, will only be able to export 2,000 pigs by the end of this year. This is less than one day's consumption of pork in Singapore.

    We will also be encouraging the importation of frozen pork from countries free from infectious animal diseases to ensure a wide range of supply at competitive prices.

PIG-WASTE POLLUTION LEVY


    9. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development how much has been collected since the imposition of the levy of $10 per pig slaughtered and for what use is such levy intended.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the pig-waste pollution levy was imposed with effect from 1st January 1980. By the end of February 1981, a sum of $10.7 million has been collected. This money will be used for the development and construction of treatment plants to treat piggery waste.

Column: 636

TREATMENT PLANT FOR PIG-WASTE


    10. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development what plans there are to build a plant for the treatment of pig-waste with a view to reducing pollution.

Column: 637



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as Singapore does not have vast tracts of arable land to dispose of pig-waste, the only feasible solution to the waste pollution problem is to treat the waste.

    The Primary Production Department is working closely with the Ministry of the Environment on a strategy for the treatment of pig-waste. Various methods of waste treatment are being studied to select the most cost-effective option. A treatment plant will be built when the Primary Production Department completes its studies.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would be grateful if the Hon. Minister could indicate to the House as to when the Primary Production Department could come to a decision on the construction of the pig-waste treatment plant?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, at present the Primary Production Department is studying the various options. I cannot give a definite date but I hope it will be in one or two years' time.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, from what the Minister has said just now, it appears to me that in the course of time pig-farming will be abolished. If there is going to be no pig-farming, what is the point of building the pig-waste treatment plant?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, what I have said earlier is that Punggol may be redeveloped in 15 to 20 years' time. This means that if we construct a pig-waste plant, this plant will be used for 15 to 20 years.

Column: 637

CAR-PARKING IN HOUSING BOARD
ESTATES


    11. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for National Development whether he plans to modify the car-park charging system to encourage children to visit and spend more time with their parents who are living in Housing and Development Board flats.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB car parks are meant for the use of

Column: 638

residents, visitors and those who have business within HDB estates. Apart from residents who pay season parking rates, other users are charged uniform rates for hourly parking. It will be very difficult to justify and implement a system of different parking charges to favour a specific category of users, namely, children visiting their parents who live in HDB flats.

    The existing hourly parking fee of 40 cents per hour at HDB car parks outside the Central Area is not exorbitant. It is unlikely that this rate of parking fees is deterring children from visiting their parents in HDB estates.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware of complaints that fines are too readily meted out to people who bring their children to their parents' house to be taken care of in the morning?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, if they have paid the parking charges, then there will be no fine.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Sir, they only park for five minutes and they have to pay 40 cents.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I do not think so. Usually we give a five-minute grace and sometimes the five-minute grace stretches to 10 minutes.

Column: 638

PROFITEERING, INFLATION, CONSUMER PRICES
AND EXPENDITURE PATTERNS


    12. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health (a) whether the Committee on Profiteering and Inflation is still functioning and, if so, what steps are being taken to ensure that causes within our control are constantly being identified and dealt with promptly; (b) whether the basket of goods and services used for the computation of Consumer Price Index still reflect the current expenditure pattern of the majority of Singapore households, particularly those living in Housing and Development Board estates; and (c) based

Column: 639

on the current Consumer Price Index, what is the minimum income required to sustain an average family of four, i.e. parents and two school-going children, living in an HDB three-room flat.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Committee on Profiteering and Inflation (CPI) meets regularly to monitor changes in prices of essential commodities, examine the causes of inflation, and consider whether and how certain price increases could be moderated. The Committee has met 66 times so far.

    Inflation in Singapore is primarily imported. As we are dependent on imports, our domestic prices are influenced by changes in the international prices of energy, raw materials and other imports. We cannot avoid the effects that world inflation will have on our domestic prices. The CPI will, however, moderate such imported inflation by long-term purchases and diversifying sources of supplies of essential commodities such as rice and sugar, whenever possible.

    The CPI, together with the Department of Trade, also look out for profiteering practices. The Department will ensure that firms do not restrict supplies of essential commodities to artificially force up prices or to profiteer.

    On the second part of the question, the current basket of goods and services used in computing the Consumer Price Index is based on the most recent household expenditure survey conducted in 1977-78. It is representative of nearly 90% of all households in Singapore with monthly expenditures of $100-$1,499. It is also representative of the expenditure pattern of 90% of households living in HDB estates.

    The last two household surveys (one conducted in 1972-73 and the other in 1977-78) showed that patterns of expenditure did not differ significantly over the five-year period. The current basket is, therefore, probably still representative of the expenditure pattern of the majority of Singapore

Column: 640

households, particularly those living in HDB estates.

    It is true, however, that with rising affluence and income, the consumption pattern of Singaporeans will change over time. To provide a more-up-to-date picture of the consumption habits of our population, the Department of Statistics will conduct another household expenditure survey next year.

    On the last part of the question, it is difficult to be exact in estimating the minimum income level required to sustain a family as it will depend on many factors, such as individual tastes, age, physical attributes of household members, distance from place of work, and so on. As a rough guide, according to data from the 1977-78 household expenditure survey, a four-person HDB household in that year had an average family income of about $860 and spent an average monthly expenditure of about $707. Allowing for wage and price increases since 1977-78, it is estimated that the average family income would now have been about $1,060 compared to an average household expenditure of about $830.

CLOSURE OF SCHOOL
(Consultation with MP and Principal)


    13. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister of Education whether, in deciding on the closure of either a primary or secondary school, it is an established procedure of his Ministry to consult the relevant Member of Parliament and principal.

     The Minister of Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, schools are closed because the enrolment is declining, the buildings and the facilities are sub-standard, or the school sites are acquired by Government for redevelopment projects. The Ministry of Education works in close consultation with the principal of the school that is affected to ensure that his staff and pupils are properly posted to other schools. Where there are unusual circumstances, the relevant Member of Parliament is consulted.

NANYANG UNIVERSITY AND TAIWAN
UNIVERSITY GRADUATES
(Rejection of applications to teach in
Secondary schools)


    14. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister of Education whether a good number of graduates of the former Nanyang University and of Taiwan universities who have been teaching in primary schools since the 1960s have had their applications to his Ministry, submitted through their principals, to teach in secondary schools rejected, and, if so, what is the reason for the rejection.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, there are at present 41 graduates of the former Nanyang University and universities in Taiwan or China who are teaching in primary schools. Prior to 1979 the Ministry did not keep records of a teacher's applications for posting. I regret, therefore, that I am not able to inform the hon. Member as to the number of unsuccessful applications prior to 1979 for transfer to secondary schools from graduates of Nanyang University or Taiwan universities. Between 1979 and now, only two teachers with these qualifications applied for transfer to secondary schools. Both applications were approved.

STREAMING
(Impact and effects)


    15. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Minister of Education whether his Ministry has looked into the psychological impact of streaming on pupils and parents and its long term effects on society.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, the Ministry of Education has taken great care in streaming pupils to the various streams in primary and secondary schools. The progress of pupils is closely monitored. The purpose of streaming, as has been repeatedly emphasized, is to enable each pupil to progress at a pace suited to his or her ability. As streaming has just been introduced, it is too early to speculate on its long-term effects on Singapore society.

Column: 642



     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Speaker, Sir, just a few supplementary questions. What were the experiences of other countries which have attempted streaming? Did they also stream the children in the same way? What were the results? Did they achieve their objective of streaming? If not, why?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, for me to attempt to give a complete answer to a general question like that would be to occupy the attention of the House for perhaps a whole year. However, I can say that the system of streaming which we have followed in our new education policy is, as far as we know, very similar to the system which is used in streaming pupils in the German education system and in those cantons in Switzerland which are German-speaking. As far as we know, the streaming has been successful and there have been no adverse effects on either children, their parents, or on German or Swiss societies.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Sir, can the Ministry assure me that they have taken steps to monitor the effects of streaming on children into special environments? Would not these highly intelligent children branch into special schools, where they play and study together, develop attitudes and prejudices peculiar to their group? Would they be able to relate to the other less academically endowed children?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not sure as to the exact point which the hon. Member is making. Can I ask him to rephrase his question?

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: If the Minister of Education were to group children of very high intellect into special schools where they only play and work together, could the Minister let me know whether they would be able to relate themselves to the less academically endowed children?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, we do not group Singapore children of very high intellect into special schools. For example, in our streaming at the secondary school level, all the schools have at least two streams, for

Column: 643

example, the Special and Express streams. I do not, therefore, see the danger, which the Member is referring to, existing in Singapore.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE ALLOWANCE
(Withdrawal of)


    16. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Acting Minister for Social Affairs (a) how many people have had their public assistance allowance withdrawn in 1980; and (b) whether his Ministry ensures that every recipient of such allowance will be able to obtain alternative assistance before it withdraws the allowance.

     The Acting Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, a total of 1,984 Public Assistance recipients had their allowances withdrawn last year, 1,586 or 80% of the total were supported by children or close relatives. Another 239 or 12% lost their allowances because either they or their family members had found employment. The remaining 159 or 8% were fit and within employable age but had refused employment.

    On the second part of the hon. Member's question, my Ministry does ensure that Public Assistance allowance is not withdrawn unless the recipient has adequate alternative means of support. In particular, a recipient will not lose his Public Assistance allowance if his relatives, themselves in difficult financial straits, can only give him occasional help. Of the 1,984 recipients who had their Public Assistance allowances withdrawn in 1980, only 152 sought other forms of assistance. They were assisted in cash and kind by private charitable funds and voluntary welfare agencies through the intervention of the Social Welfare Department.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, despite the Hon. Minister's assurance that the Public Assistance allowance is not withdrawn unless the recipient has adequate alternative means of support, I still receive a large number of appeals from

Column: 644

constituents who complain about the stoppage of public assistance allowance. I am sure many of my colleagues in this House face the same problems with their constituents.

     Some hon. Members: Yes.
